title: Quiz 1: NCK Paper One - January 2013
description: Licensure Examination covering General Nursing, Medical-Surgical Nursing, and Ethics (January 2013).

questions.question: When the nurse commits her/himself to actively promote patients well being, she/he is practicing the principle of:
questions.explanation: Beneficence is the ethical principle of acting in the best interest of the patient and actively promoting their well-being. It goes beyond just 'doing no harm' (non-maleficence).
questions.hint: Think about the action of 'doing good' versus just avoiding harm.

questions.question: The features that suggest a fracture of the base of the skull include:

options.text: Glasgow coma scale of 5, constricted pupils

questions.explanation: Basal skull fractures are characterized by specific signs including CSF leakage from the ears (otorrhea), and hemorrhagic signs like periorbital ecchymosis (Raccoon eyes) and mastoid ecchymosis (Battle's sign). Sub-conjunctival bleeding can also occur.
questions.hint: Look for signs involving leakage of fluid from the ear or specific bleeding patterns around the eyes/ears.

questions.question: The risk factors for Guillain-Barre Syndrome are:

options.text: Influenza immunization, infection with Neisseria meningitides

questions.explanation: Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is often preceded by an infection. Campylobacter jejuni enteritis is the most common antecedent infection. Surgery and trauma are also known triggers.
questions.hint: This condition often follows a gastrointestinal infection.

questions.question: The causes of acute interstitial nephritis include:

options.text: Allergy to penicillin, acute bacterial pyelonephritis

questions.explanation: Acute Interstitial Nephritis (AIN) is most commonly caused by hypersensitivity reactions to drugs (like penicillins) and infections (like pyelonephritis).
questions.hint: Think about allergic reactions to common antibiotics.

questions.question: Structures in the middle ear include:
questions.explanation: The middle ear cavity communicates with the nasopharynx via the Eustachian tube and is separated from the inner ear by the round and oval windows. The cochlea and semicircular canals are inner ear structures.
questions.hint: Exclude structures that belong to the inner ear (cochlea) or external ear (auditory canal).

questions.question: The clinical manifestations of exfoliative dermatitis include:
questions.explanation: Exfoliative dermatitis (erythroderma) involves widespread erythema (redness) and scaling (exfoliation) of the skin, typically affecting more than 90% of the body surface area.
questions.hint: The name of the condition implies shedding of skin.

questions.question: The limitations of ultrasound in gastro-enterology include:

options.text: Has low sensitivity for small lesions, obesity obscures the images
Exposes one to high radiation dose, cannot be used on a patient who has metallic prosthesis
Is expensive, has little functional information
It may under stage some tumors. Its role in gastro-intestinal diseases has not been fully investigated

questions.explanation: Ultrasound waves are attenuated by subcutaneous fat (making obesity a limitation) and are reflected by gas (making bowel gas a barrier).
questions.hint: Think about what physical properties (fat, gas, bone) interfere with sound waves.

questions.question: High risk category of patients should be considered for specific antithrombotic prophylaxis, which include those undergoing:

options.text: Hip surgery, pelvic surgery for removal of malignancy
Treatment for major medical conditions such as pneumonia and HIV/AIDS
Knee surgery, treatment for heart failure
Antiretroviral therapy, inflammatory bowel syndrome management

questions.explanation: Major orthopedic surgery (hip/knee replacement) and major cancer surgery (especially pelvic/abdominal) carry the highest risk for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) and Pulmonary Embolism (PE).
questions.hint: Major surgeries involving the lower limbs or pelvis carry the highest clot risk.

questions.question: The most appropriate drugs for the management of nausea and vomiting in palliative care are:
questions.explanation: Metoclopramide is effective for gastric stasis, and Scopolamine is effective for motion sickness, bowel obstruction, and drying secretions in palliative care.
questions.hint: Identify the option containing two anti-emetics (not stool softeners or antihistamines).

questions.question: The clinical features of open angle glaucoma include:

options.text: Slow loss of sight, loss of visual field, cupping of the optic disc
Blurred vision, corneal oedema, red eye
Rapid loss of vision, dilated pupil, severe eye pain
Constricted pupil, very painful eye, blurred vision

questions.explanation: Primary Open Angle Glaucoma (POAG) is typically asymptomatic in early stages, causing gradual, painless loss of peripheral vision and pathological cupping of the optic disc.
questions.hint: This condition is often called the 'silent thief of sight' because it happens slowly and painlessly.

questions.question: To identify the bowel sounds the nurse will place a warmed diaphragm of the stethoscope on:

options.text: All the quadrants of the abdomen towards the umbilicus
All the nine regions of the abdomen

questions.explanation: Standard assessment involves listening in all four quadrants to ensure motility is present throughout. The stethoscope is typically placed lightly near the umbilicus in each quadrant.
questions.hint: A comprehensive assessment requires checking all major areas.

questions.question: The technique used to determine the mobility of abdominal organs is:
questions.explanation: Palpation (specifically deep palpation or ballottement) is used to assess organs for size, shape, consistency, and mobility.
questions.hint: Which technique involves feeling the organs with hands?

questions.question: The dosage of rectal diazepam for a 4 year old child weighing 15kgs is:

richContent.content:
Calculation Note:

  • Standard pediatric rectal diazepam dose: 0.5 mg/kg
  • Standard concentration: 5 mg/mL

questions.explanation: Calculation: 15 kg × 0.5 mg/kg = 7.5 mg. Volume: 7.5 mg ÷ 5 mg/mL = 1.5 mL.
questions.hint: Calculate the total milligrams required using 0.5 mg/kg first.

questions.question: Manifestations of hypothyroidism in the reproductive system include:

options.text: Anovulation, high incidence of spontaneous abortion

questions.explanation: Hypothyroidism disrupts the hormonal axis, often leading to anovulatory cycles, infertility, menorrhagia, and increased risk of miscarriage (spontaneous abortion).
questions.hint: Hypothyroidism generally 'slows down' body systems but can cause irregular/heavy cycles and fertility issues.

questions.question: The causes of exertional dyspnea include:
questions.explanation: Exertional dyspnea typically indicates chronic or progressive lung/heart disease like bronchial carcinoma and pneumoconiosis. The other options usually present with acute dyspnea.
questions.hint: Look for chronic conditions rather than acute emergencies.

questions.question: Sinus bradycardia contributes to:

options.text: Decreased filling times, increased mean pressure
Decreased mean arterial pressure, increased preload
Increased filling times, increased mean arterial pressure

questions.explanation: Bradycardia increases the duration of diastole, which increases ventricular filling time and thus increases preload. This can help maintain MAP.
questions.hint: A slower heart rate allows more time for the heart chambers to fill with blood.

questions.question: The function of niacin in the body is:

options.text: Inhibition of production of cholesterol, is necessary for cell respiration
Formation of collagen is necessary for red blood cell maturation
Is necessary for DNA synthesis, is antioxidant

questions.explanation: Niacin (Vitamin B3) is a precursor for NAD and NADP, coenzymes essential for redox reactions in the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins.
questions.hint: This B-vitamin plays a key role in energy metabolism.

questions.question: As regards the process of inflammation, release of histamine is triggered when:

options.text: Cells degranulate and antibody titre is low
Platelets are activated and mast cells degranulate
Mast cells degranulate and basophils depressed
Binding of antibody to mast cells and basophils occur

questions.explanation: Histamine is stored in mast cell granules. Release (degranulation) occurs when an antigen binds to IgE antibodies attached to the mast cell surface or through other activation pathways involving platelets.
questions.hint: Focus on the specific cell type known for storing histamine granules.

questions.question: The child has foreign body aspiration and probably NOT laryngo-tracheobronchitis (croup) if there is:

options.text: Hoarse voice, stridor of gradual onset
Sudden onset of stridor, upper respiratory tract infection
Focal reduced air entry, sudden onset of respiratory distress

questions.explanation: Foreign body aspiration typically presents with a sudden onset of symptoms in a previously well child, often with focal findings (like reduced air entry on one side). Croup has a gradual onset with URI symptoms.
questions.hint: Foreign bodies often block one specific airway, causing asymmetric findings.

questions.question: The risks associated with knee-chest position when the patient is on the operation table for a long period of time includes:

options.text: Venous pooling as blood shifts to the lower extremities
Damage to arterial plexus derived from internal iliac arteries
Deep venous thrombosis in the lower extremities

questions.explanation: Prolonged positioning in knee-chest position can cause venous stasis in the lower extremities due to compression and gravity, increasing the risk of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).
questions.hint: Prolonged immobility and venous compression are classic risk factors for this vascular complication.

questions.question: Which of the following are body surface defenses against infection? (Select 4)
questions.explanation: The body's surface defenses include the physical barrier of intact skin, mucus trapping in membranes, cilia sweeping pathogens out, and chemical barriers like the acid mantle and lysozyme.
questions.hint: Think about barriers that exist on the surface or lining of the body, not internal immune cells.

questions.question: Which interventions are appropriate in the management of atopic dermatitis?
questions.explanation: Management involves restoring the skin barrier with emollients, avoiding triggers like harsh soaps, and using pharmacotherapy like topical steroids or antihistamines for symptoms.
questions.hint: Focus on keeping the skin moist and reducing inflammation.

questions.question: Arrange the steps in the pathophysiology of Rheumatoid Arthritis in the correct order:
questions.explanation: The process starts with an autoimmune attack, leading to inflammation (synovitis), growth of destructive tissue (pannus), erosion of the joint, and finally deformity and fusion.
questions.hint: Start with the initial trigger and end with the permanent structural changes.

questions.question: Which factors may necessitate hospital admission for a 3-year-old child with asthma? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Low Oxygen Saturation (< 92% on room air)
Mild wheezing with good air entry

questions.explanation: Admission is required for severe signs like distress, hypoxia, silent chest (impending failure), altered consciousness, dehydration, or failure of home management.
questions.hint: Select the signs that indicate the child is in danger or home treatment isn't working.

questions.question: Arrange the steps in the pathophysiology of H. pylori infection:

items.text: Colonization and burrowing through mucus layer
Production of urease to neutralize acid
Ammonia and cytotoxins damage epithelial cells
Ulcer formation due to mucosal compromise

questions.explanation: The bacteria first colonize, then protect themselves with urease/ammonia, cause direct damage with toxins, triggering inflammation, and finally ulceration.
questions.hint: The bacteria must first survive the acid environment before causing damage.

questions.question: Match the developmental factor with its effect on drug action:
questions.explanation: Organ immaturity in infants (liver/kidney) slows metabolism and excretion. Body composition changes (water/fat) affect distribution. Protein levels affect free drug availability.
questions.hint: Connect the organ/system with its primary pharmacokinetic function (metabolism, excretion, distribution).
